page.title: 06FLORA AROUND OAKAMOOR
page.content: Legend says that if the ancient chained oak in Barbary Gutter falls, that Alton will fall into the Churnet.The oak and Alton still stand but much of the deciduous woodland has disappeared. There is now a predominance of coniferous plantations of pines and larches,inter- mingled with deciduous trees such as oak and sycamore.A lone elm still grows on the Ranger and alders grow along the riverbanks. Violets, primroses and many wildflowers grow on the disused railway line which is exceedingly rich in plants and insects.Dingy ,grizzled and small skippers are to be found as well as the common blue and many other butterflies. Indian balsalm has colonised the river banks,and the very rare insectivorous sundew grows in just one isolated spot. There are few rich meadows left unspoiled by man.
